精彩（和诡异！）万圣节摄影的 13 个技巧帖子首先出现在数码摄影学校。它的作者是达伦·罗斯。

万圣节提供了一些令人难以置信的景象，但用相机捕捉这一切可能很棘手。幸运的是，只要掌握正确的技巧和技巧，就可以拍摄出精美的照片来纪念幽灵般的景象、清新的秋天空气，以及最重要的乐趣！

在这篇文章中，我将分享许多有关美丽万圣节摄影的建议，包括：

  • 拍摄恐怖照片的照明技巧
  • 万圣节拍照的好地方
  • 拍摄孩子和他们可爱的服装的简单方法
  • 有趣的万圣节拍照创意
  • 多得多！

因此，如果您准备好在一年中最可怕的一天拿起相机，那么让我们开始吧！

1. 包括幽灵或大气的万圣节道具

万圣节有很多物品，从南瓜、服装到骷髅、蝙蝠和鬼魂。

所以使用它们。如果您要拍摄万圣节照片，请带上一两个道具。让孩子们抱着鬼魂；让你的配偶透过骷髅窥视；让你的宠物穿上南瓜服装并近距离拍摄它们。您可以使用更恐怖的道具（例如假血），也可以坚持使用更可爱的道具（例如南瓜），或者您可以将两者结合起来以获得可爱和恐怖的图像。

这张照片使用了一个看起来令人毛骨悚然的南瓜灯来增添大量的气氛：

有时，正如上图所示，仅靠道具就可以拍出很棒的照片。您可以拍摄万圣节墓碑、装饰着蝙蝠和鬼魂的房屋等的美丽照片。

不过，不要只拍快照。确保您仔细注意构图（请参阅下面的提示）和照明（再次请参阅我的附加提示），并尽您所能用相机讲述一个有趣的故事。

2. 突出显示相关兴趣点

如果您追求出色的万圣节摄影——怪异的、可爱的或介于两者之间的任何东西——您通常应该包括一个焦点，一些观众立即优先考虑的关键“英雄”元素。

例如，如果您要为穿着服装的孩子拍照，请让他们成为关注的焦点。确保您使用干净的背景（没有任何干扰！）和裸露的前景。调整相机设置，使孩子的脸部清晰且曝光良好。

当然，您始终可以在照片中包含次要主题或物品。但它们不应该成为优先事项，一旦它们开始分散主要主题的注意力，你就应该将它们从你的作品中排除。

看看下一张恐怖的万圣节照片；女人是主要主体，酒杯是次要主体：

背景相对干净，没有任何干扰，观看者的视线直接移向女人的脸、杯子和背部。该图像也非常具有万圣节风格。看看黑暗的背景、橙色的颜色和奇妙的恐怖气氛！

底线：

在按下快门之前，问问自己：“这张照片的焦点是什么？”并尽一切努力来强调它。

3.找到合适的位置

虽然从技术上讲，您可以在任何地方进行万圣节摄影，但找到一个与您想要营造的氛围相匹配的地点通常是值得的。

例如，如果您想拍摄可爱的万圣节照片，请考虑拍摄：

  • 在你后院的树叶中
  • 在你的厨房里
  • 在万圣节派对上

如果您想拍摄恐怖的万圣节照片，请尝试拍摄：

  • 在地下室
  • 在森林中央
  • 晚上在一个小区

（当然，您应该始终将安全放在首位；切勿仅仅为了拍摄恐怖照片而将自己置于不舒服的境地。）

在计划万圣节拍摄时，我鼓励您坐下来考虑不同的地点想法。我敢打赌您会在附近找到很多拍摄万圣节照片的地方 - 您只需要进行一些集思广益即可！

4.让画面充满万圣节气氛

万圣节是戏剧性的时刻。您可以通过近距离拍摄来在图像中传达这一点，以便您用拍摄对象填充画面。

如果您要为穿着戏服的孩子拍照，请确保画面周围没有无聊、空洞的边缘。相反，请放大（或靠近），以便相机捕捉到每一个小细节。

不过，没有必要太过分。不要走得太远，以免镜头无法对焦，也不要走得太近，以免观众无法理解照片的内容。相反，确定您的主题（请参阅前面的提示！），使其成为注意力的中心，然后放大。

还有一件事：如果你的主要主题看起来不够万圣节风格，可以考虑用额外的装饰品、服装、小饰品等来给它们增添趣味。万圣节越多通常会更好！

5. 给受试者空间去研究

这是一个快速的万圣节肖像摄影技巧，可以确保更好的构图：

在拍摄图像之前，请注意拍摄对象的脸部和眼睛的方向。然后调整相机取景，直到拍摄对象的视线前方有足够的空间。

这可能看起来很奇怪，但它实际上有助于平衡构图。它还增加了一种活力感，观众被迫在整个镜头中跟随拍摄对象的目光。 （事实上​​，这种方法甚至还有一个名字： 空间法则。）

这是一个很好的例子：

两个男孩向下看，取景在场景底部附近有足够的空间（注意他们的眼睛有足够的空间可以看！）。

6.寻找非常规的角度和前景来增加恐怖感

想要拍摄一些恐怖的万圣节摄影吗？请仔细注意下一个提示。

你看，创造节日寒冷感的一个好方法是通过透视。事实上，是通过低位——深入泥土！ – 你会让你的主题在观众面前显得更加突出。如果使用广角镜头拍摄，效果尤其强烈。

当然，您还需要添加可怕的道具，例如蝙蝠、大锅和鬼魂。这样，您就可以创建一个令人毛骨悚然的万圣节图像，让您的拍摄对象看起来从地面出现并站在观看者上方的高处。

另一个快速提示：

尝试后退，在拍摄对象前面放置一个有趣的前景元素。当然，您不想添加任何分散注意力的东西。但在拍摄对象前面放置一两根深色树枝可以极大地增强气氛。

7. 拍摄小细节

万圣节的华丽部分很容易让人分心。但通常当你退后一步，环顾四周，注意到更小的细节时，你就会发现赚钱的镜头。

万圣节充满了值得捕捉的有趣小时刻。有：

  • 装饰
  • 南瓜雕刻的乐趣
  • 实际雕刻的南瓜
  • 人们盛装打扮
  • 晚上结束时有很多糖果
  • 派对和/或“不给糖就捣蛋”活动结束后，孩子们正在睡觉
  • 食物的特写镜头

不要让这些时刻从你身边溜走。相反，请留意——当你看到值得记录的记忆时，就记录下来。几年后，这些亲密的照片将讲述万圣节的真实故事，你会很高兴捕捉到它们。

8. 别忘了合影！

万圣节是有趣的聚会和聚会的时刻，这意味着您将有很多机会拍摄合影。

因此，拿出更宽焦距的镜头，让每个人都排列成一组，然后拍摄一些图像。考虑寻找一个更高的有利位置（如果您在室内，请尝试使用踏脚凳；如果您在室外，请考虑一些台阶甚至屋顶）。

当然，请确保每个人都拿起一两个道具并穿上他们的服装。并要求他们都做出最可怕的表情！一些有趣的万圣节摄影创意包括：

  • 大家都围着一个大锅
  • 人们都躲在灌木丛里
  • 每个人都围着一本书、一块墓碑或一只巨型蜘蛛转圈

9. 捕捉低光剪影以获得诡异效果

想到万圣节，脑海中浮现的图像类型都是黑暗而可怕的：南瓜里的蜡烛、夜晚的蝙蝠、以及晚上走来走去的神秘猫。

那么为什么不尝试自己制作一些恐怖的万圣节照片呢？这比你想象的要容易。您只需使用低光剪影技术，即可获得如下图像：

它的工作原理如下：

首先，找到一个能够形成良好剪影的主题。它应该有清晰的边缘，并且最好是可识别的，就像上面照片中的猫一样。

然后等到太阳落山，你就会看到橙色、红色或黄色的天空。将自己置于拍摄对象和日落之间，然后蹲下，直到拍摄对象在美丽的背景下取景。

您需要关闭闪光灯，我建议将图像曝光不足以获得较暗的效果。您可以通过以下两种方式进行操作：

  • 提高快门速度，边走边试拍。您可能需要从 1/100 秒左右开始，具体取决于黑暗程度，然后增加到 1/250 秒、1/500 秒或更高。 （记住：按下快门按钮后立即查看每张图像！）
  • 缩小光圈（再次，一路上进行大量测试拍摄）。这将使您的照片变暗，但也会增加景深，从而锐化背景，这可能是好是坏，具体取决于您的目标。

不管怎样，我们的想法是获得一个相对黑暗、喜怒无常的图像，所以不用担心照片看起来曝光不足。只需在中等亮度的背景下拍摄一点剪影细节，效果就会很棒。

10.使用闪光凝胶进行大气的万圣节摄影

这是过去的读者建议的一个聪明的万圣节摄影想法：

找到某种彩色玻璃纸（橙色、黄色和红色都可以），然后将其放在闪光灯上。当您拍摄时，玻璃纸将充当闪光凝胶，改变光线颜色以获得美丽的效果。

（如果找不到彩色玻璃纸，只需用橙色记号笔在透明玻璃纸上画画即可！）

如果您计划拍摄万圣节照片，您可能需要提前测试一下，因为您需要仔细应用正确密度的玻璃纸（一张与两张或三张等）。但如果做得好，效果绝对是奇妙的，可以拍出一些令人惊叹的万圣节照片。

顺便说一句，无论您有相机弹出式闪光灯、手持式离机闪光灯还是完整的工作室设置，都没有关系。无论您的设备如何，您都可以使用此技巧；你一定会得到华丽的结果！

11. 也给南瓜灯拍照吧！

南瓜灯是万圣节的经典，没有什么比捕捉发光南瓜的美丽照片更令人满足的了。因此，请务必花一点时间将相机对准一两个南瓜灯！

现在，拍摄南瓜灯可能很棘手，因为您需要捕捉南瓜的外部和内部发光，这有点像在过度曝光和曝光不足之间走钢丝。如果可以的话，用不同的快门速度拍几张照片。并考虑在后期处理中使用高动态范围技术包围曝光和混合。

（如果您确实决定使用 HDR 技术，我鼓励您将相机安装在三脚架上；这将使混合过程变得更加容易。）

12.尝试一些悬浮摄影

悬浮效果很容易实现，当你将它与深色衣服和恐怖风格的道具结合起来时，你最终会感到毛骨悚然——甚至可怕！ – 万圣节照片。

首先，找到一个能增添很多气氛的好地方，比如黑暗的森林。

确保你的拍摄对象穿着足够万圣节风格的服装（女巫和妖精服装非常适合这一点）。

带上某种支撑元件，例如凳子，然后让你的拍摄对象站在或躺在上面。拍摄一张让拍摄对象摆出怪异姿势的照片。然后移开凳子，让拍摄对象站在一边，拍摄第二张（没有凳子）仅包含背景的图像。确保使用与以前完全相同的设置（包括焦点）。

当您回到家时，只需将这两个文件导入 Photoshop， 遮盖凳子，您就会得到一张完美的万圣节悬浮照片！

13. 进行一些万圣节风格的编辑

虽然外出拍摄时尽力而为始终很重要，但您可以通过在 Lightroom 或 Photoshop 中进行一些后期处理来大幅改善您的万圣节照片。

首先，看看是否可以通过提高对比度和降低黑色来增加恐怖气氛。

然后尝试不同的颜色分级效果。例如，您可以使用Lightroom 颜色分级面板将绿色添加到阴影，将橙色添加到高光。您还可以调整白平衡以创建橙色或蓝色效果（两者都可以看起来很棒，具体取决于您想要创建的内容）。

如果您想要真正狂野，请考虑在 Photoshop 中添加深色、蹩脚的纹理。这样，你就可以真正推销“恐怖”的外观了！

玻璃球摄影是创造引人注目的图像的绝佳方式，这种方式会让您的观众惊叹又好奇。

但玻璃球照片如何发挥作用呢？如何设置漂亮的图像？如何使用一个简单的水晶球来捕捉如此引人注目的效果？

在这篇文章中，我将分享您入门所需的一切，包括镜头球推荐、大量技巧，甚至一些水晶球摄影创意。

让我们开始吧。

玻璃球摄影如何工作？

玻璃球摄影，也称为水晶球摄影，利用折射来捕捉独特的图像。将水晶球（ lensball ）放置在场景前面；然后场景在球中折射。由于物理的魔力，你最终会在球中得到一个倒置的图像，然后你可以用相机捕捉到它。

作为摄影师，您对镜头图像拥有最终控制权。例如，通过重新定位球（以及通过相对于球重新定位相机），您将捕捉到不同的视角。您还可以调整光圈以获得浅景深效果（球被模糊的背景框住），并且可以更改相机到球的距离以获得有趣的特写效果。我将在下面更详细地讨论这些技术。

1.考虑翻转颠倒的图像

由于折射，玻璃球内的图像发生了翻转。这意味着您有两个选择：

  1. 您可以保留倒立的图像并将其合并到构图中。例如，您可以将翻转的图像与背景中的真实场景并置。
  2. 您可以在后处理过程中旋转图像，使球的图像正面朝上显示。在这里，你可能想用大光圈虚化背景；这样，翻转的背景就不明显了。

正如您将在本文中看到的，我使用了多种技术。有时，我喜欢保留倒置的水晶球图像。其他时候，我会翻转图像以获得不那么令人迷惑的效果。

顺便说一句，如果您想创建清晰的正面朝上的图像，但不想在后期处理中进行任何旋转，还有另一种选择：

您可以使用球来拍摄倒影。毕竟，反射自然是颠倒的，但球会将它们颠倒以获得看起来正常的结果。

2. 与你的主题保持一致

将玻璃球放在地上并向其射击可能很诱人，但这实际上会导致显着的变形，而且会产生较小的构图影响。

相反，我建议将球抬离地面并与拍摄对象保持同一水平。这里的关键是确保您的拍摄对象位于球的中心，因此请随意移动设置，直到获得您想要的构图。

请注意，您需要将手放在画面之外，这样您可以近距离拍摄球的一部分，也可以将球放在高架平台上，例如岩石、汽车或汽车。长椅。

当然，这个建议也有例外。有时，将球放在地上是值得的，特别是如果您打算拍摄水坑或叶床。

3. 将您的拍摄对象填充到玻璃球中

除非你靠近你的拍摄对象，否则它在球内会显得非常小。因此，尽你所能拉近距离，直到你的拍摄对象在球（以及框架）中显得很大。

这可能需要仔细的计划甚至一些创造力。球就像一个广角镜头，因此请尝试将您的镜头想象为以 16 毫米左右的距离拍摄。场景会以 16 毫米充满画面吗？如果是这样，你就是黄金！

4.选择正确的镜头

是的，您几乎可以使用任何镜头进行玻璃球摄影，从超广角到超远摄。但如果你想最大限度地发挥球的影响，我真的建议使用微距镜头（或具有显着近距对焦功能的长焦镜头）。

借助微距镜头，您可以靠近球，这有两个作用：

  1. 它可以让您增加击球中球的大小（换句话说，您可以近距离观察很多细节）。
  2. 它可以帮助您创建强烈的背景散景，如果您想翻转图像并保持其自然的外观，这是关键（在技巧 1 中讨论）。

广角镜头也可以使用，但前提是场景允许。我建议尝试使用微距镜头和广角镜头来确定您最喜欢的效果。

5.选择正确的光圈

光圈影响景深（即聚焦的场景量）。

设置超宽光圈，您最终会得到美丽的模糊背景和清晰的前景。设置超窄光圈，您最终会得到清晰的前景和清晰的背景。

两者显然并不比另一个更好。这仅取决于您想要的效果。如果您想要创建模糊的背景（例如，您想要翻转图像而不产生令人迷惑的结果），您可以尝试使用 f/4 左右的光圈。这通常会模糊背景，同时在球内创建清晰的图像。

但之后请务必查看液晶显示屏上的图像，以确保获得所需的结果。如果距离太远，连球都会模糊，一切都会变得失焦混乱。此外，景深还取决于其他因素，例如镜头球和相机之间的距离，因此进行实验总是一个好主意。

6. 找到一个安全的位置来放置球

这非常重要，尤其是当您从高处拍摄时。球就是球，这意味着它们喜欢滚动，你当然不希望你的水晶球从长凳上滚下来（或更糟糕的是，从建筑物上滚下来）。最好的情况是，它最终会出现划痕，而最坏的情况是，它会摔碎，你需要购买一个新的。

这就是为什么我建议将球放在平坦的表面上，缝隙更好（如果你能找到的话）。小心地放置球，然后让它静置几秒钟。即使球看起来很稳定，也要将你（或朋友）的手放在附近，像鹰一样观察它，尤其是在有风的日子里。您肯定不希望球在照片中间吹走！

如果你找不到一个好的休息的地方，你可以请朋友帮你抱球。或者，经过一些练习，您可以自己握住球（尽管这总是很棘手；除非您使用三脚架，否则您需要用一只手握住球，同时用另一只手对焦并按下快门！） 。

7. 确保拍摄对象光线充足

几乎每张照片都可以受益于光线充足的拍摄对象，但这对于水晶球摄影尤其重要。

为什么？强光照射的拍摄对象会穿过球，同时最大限度地减少反射。 （是的，那些来自球前方的讨厌的反射可以显示出不需要的元素，例如相机镜头！）

这就是为什么我建议您在阳光位于身后并直接照射到拍摄对象的情况下进行拍摄。或者，您可以在蓝色时段或夜间拍摄，但目标是拍摄具有明亮外墙的建筑物。

（另一方面，反射可以创造有趣的效果，所以如果您有创意，请不要害怕尝试不同的照明场景。）

玻璃球摄影与标准摄影

您是否想知道从事玻璃球摄影是否有意义？毕竟，当您可以拍摄同一场景的美丽广角照片时，您真的想使用镜头球吗？

在本节中，我快速列出了优点和缺点 - 这将帮助您确定水晶球摄影是否适合您。

玻璃球专业人士

  • 玻璃球比镜头便宜，可让您创造出独特的鱼眼效果
  • 球提供灵活性；您可以将其移动到场景中的不同位置
  • 您可以使用大光圈与球结合来创建散景
  • 用水晶球创造的场景往往更有艺术感
  • 球为您的场景创造了一个自然的框架

玻璃球缺点

  • 较大的玻璃球携带起来很重（在已经很重的相机包中）
  • 您需要微距镜头才能获得最佳效果
  • 玻璃球的边缘产生扭曲
  • 在球内获得清晰的图像可能很困难
  • 球中的图像是颠倒的，这给你带来了另一个需要解决的问题

色彩能唤起情感——所以如果你能成为色彩大师，那么你的多彩风景摄影将会深刻地影响观众。

您可能了解曝光，像向导一样控制相机，拥有最好的设备，到达最异国情调的地点，并且擅长编辑。但如果你不刻意地在你的图像中注入有意的情感，他们永远不会对你的观看者“说话”（或者如果你的照片确实说话，他们可能会说错话）。

这就是颜色派上用场的地方。让我们通过七个色彩丰富的风景摄影技巧来学习色彩语言以及如何使用它（这将使您的图像更上一层楼！）。

1.了解色彩心理学

人类的大脑天生就会对不同的颜色做出反应。心理学家已经对此进行了研究，广告商巧妙地利用了它，并且要成为一名优秀的摄影师，您需要了解不同的颜色会给观众带来怎样的感受。

以下是颜色产生的感觉：

  • 红色：令人兴奋、重要、热情、愤怒、号召性用语
  • 紫色：美丽、异国情调、皇家、奢华、感性
  • 蓝色：平静、安详、值得信赖、寒冷
  • 绿色：平和、宁静、自然、生机、成长
  • 橙色——有趣、温暖、充满活力
  • 黄色——快乐、阳光、明亮
  • 棕色——朴实、接地气、力量、可靠性
  • 黑色——神秘、优雅、大胆、强大、前卫
  • 白色——干净、健康、纯净、无菌、冰冷

2. 色彩关系和色轮

在彩色风景摄影中，我们通常无法选择拍摄对象的颜色。也就是说，如果我们了解不同的颜色关系，我们就可以制作出更好的照片。

您可能熟悉色轮（如下所示）。当我们讨论关键颜色关系时请看一下它：

  • 互补色——这些颜色在色轮上彼此相对。它们在照片中表现得很好；例如，蓝色（通常是天空色）和橙色/棕色（通常是大地色）。因此，天空/陆地照片可以令人愉悦，因为颜色是互补的。看看下面的一些例子！
  • 类似颜色——这些就是我们所说的“颜色系列”。例如，蓝色、蓝绿色、绿色和黄绿色在色轮上彼此相邻，因此相似。我们经常可以用类似颜色的场景拍摄出令人愉悦、色彩缤纷的风景照片。
  • Color triads – These are three colors equally spaced out on the color wheel. For example, green, violet, and orange. If you look carefully, you will find color triads in nature, and they can help create impactful photos.

3. Pay careful attention to the time of day

You won't be involved in landscape photography for long before you'll hear the terms “ golden hour ” and “ blue hour .” Golden hour is the time of the day when the sun is rising or setting. The color of the light is very warm and golden.

Well before sunrise or later in the evening after sunset we have the blue hour. The sky is not dark and black. Instead, it's very cool and blue in tone. Blue hour can produce interesting light and color with a whole different mood.

I've seen new and inexperienced landscape photographers come to shoot a sunset and make shots right up until the sun dipped below the horizon. Then they'd pack up and leave. That's a mistake! The best sky color often comes well after the sun is already down. And if you wait even longer, the blue hour comes and continues until it gets truly dark.

Do enough colorful landscape photography during the sunrise/sunset/blue hour times and you run the risk of becoming a “light snob,” only wanting to make photos when the light and colors are “pretty.” (Shooting during midday? You must be joking!)

However, you won't always have the luxury of getting to places during great light. Plus, even if you do, conditions won't always cooperate. Many photographers can make nice photos of a spectacular sunset, but it's the great photographers who can create impactful images at any time of day in any kind of light (and in any kind of weather).

4. Think about the season

Colorful landscape photography knows no season. There are great images to be made year round. But when planning a photo outing, you may want to consider how to take advantage of the colors of the season.

In the spring, colorful flowers and fresh green fields make for great subjects. Summer brings bright golden days, the sun and sand colors of the beach, bright colors and sunny scenes. Autumn is often a photographer's dream with fall colors that delight the eye. Winter might be the least colorful season, but brilliant whites and deep cold blues are still impactful.

In any season, you can use color to communicate with your viewer. How do you want the photo to make them feel? Use color to carry that message: the cool blue tones of a winter's day, the bright and happy yellow color of a field of flowers, the peaceful greens of a forest, or the fiery reds and oranges of a summer sunset.

When composing , shooting, and editing, give conscious thought to the colors you're trying to bring out and what they say to your viewer.

For the best colorful landscape photography, make sure to consider what's in season. When do the camas flowers bloom? When are the aspens at peak yellow color? When are the fields in the Palouse Country deep green or golden? What is the best time to get a moonless dark night and have the Milky Way high in the sky?

If you hope to get the very best colorful landscape photos, you need to do your homework, develop good information sources, and be ready to go when things are just right.

The old saying holds true: “Luck happens when preparation meets opportunity.”

5. Shoot when the weather is bad

If you're a “fair-weather photographer,” someone who only gets out when the skies are clear and the weather is comfortable, then you're missing some of the best colorful landscape photography.

Here's another saying for you: “When the weather gets bad, the photos get good.” It may not be pleasant, but I'll take a cold, stormy day with dramatic clouds, interesting light, and striking color over a clear, cloudless, warm bluebird day (if my goal is impactful landscape photography).

The same goes for rainy, foggy, or snowy days. Don't think that good color always means contrasty, heavily saturated scenes. Watch for the more muted color and low contrast provided by inclement weather conditions.

Bright, saturated colors might be more impactful, but soft pastels and muted colors create mood and carry a completely different feel and message.

Once again, ask yourself, “How do I want to make the viewer feel?” Capture photos that speak your message and use color as your “words.”

6. Carefully edit colors for the best results

There are many good articles about how to edit color. That is not my intent here. Instead, I'll offer some general things to keep in mind when editing colors in your photos.

  • Shoot in RAW . You greatly limit your options if you only shoot and save JPEG images. The most obvious reason to shoot RAW is the flexibility to adjust the white balance later in editing rather than trying to get it right when shooting. Warming or cooling an image by adjusting the color temperature slider becomes much more difficult if you're trying to overcome the wrong white balance baked into a JPEG.
  • Understand the difference between global and local adjustment tools. Sometimes, you might want to adjust the color of the entire image – so global adjustment sliders and controls work fine. Other times, you might want to make the sky bluer without affecting the land below or bring up the saturation of just the red flowers in a landscape; such edits will require the use of local adjustment tools. If your objective is to communicate with color, knowing how to carefully and precisely control specific colors in your image is an important skill to master.
  • Don't overprocess. How much is too much? That's a judgment call, but let me express a personal bias. Just as you can over-salt a meal, you can also oversaturate a color photo. Glowing “postcard color” is not a good look if you want to be taken seriously as a landscape photographer. Neither is a grungy HDR . I believe in using color to creatively speak a message, but I don't want it to shout.

7. Make it monochrome

Sometimes, color is not the best way to give your image the most impact or communicate your message. Here are some reasons you might want to go monochrome instead:

  • The image is more about the “bones” of a good image: shape, form, tone, and texture. The color is an unnecessary distraction.
  • The image is almost monochrome anyway and the color isn't adding anything.
  • Black and white might better capture the old, nostalgic, or period feel of the image.
  • In some genres of photography such as photojournalism or street photography, black and white offers a gritty reality.
  • You want to create a lot of drama. You can often push a monochrome edit far, whereas the same amount of processing on a color image might look garish or just plain bad.
  • You are unable to get good colors, so you save your image with a black and white conversion. It's the last reason to favor monochrome, but it happens. That said, the choice to go color or black and white should be intentional rather than a rescue mission. Good photographers know their intent for a shot before they make it. But realistically, the fix for a bad color image might be a conversion to monochrome. While editing, you might think, “I wonder how this will look in black and white?” Also, this circles back to something I said earlier: Always shoot in RAW. Your images will be in color – but should you later decide black and white is preferable, it's an easy conversion.

Colorful landscape photography: final words

Imagine your photograph is printed and hanging on the wall of a gallery. You are not there, only the image and the viewer.

Now, what do you want the viewer to see, think, feel, hear, smell, and experience when looking at your photo? You are not there to interpret, explain, justify, or defend. Your photo must speak for itself.

Once you determine what you want the image to say, apply all the “visual words” at your disposal, many of which use the language of color. Do it well, and you'll be a master of colorful landscape photography.

How can I use color theory in photography?

Understand the relationships between colors, such as complementary colors, analogous colors, and color triads. That way, you can create pleasing color photos.

How can I create better color landscape photos?

When you make a color landscape photo, consider what you want it to communicate to your viewer. Then work with the colors in that image when composing, capturing, and editing – so that the colors of the image “speak” to your viewer. Understand how different colors carry different feelings. Use the feelings to create more impactful images.

Should my landscape photos be color or black and white?

The answer is that it depends. If the idea is to concentrate on the basics, such as the shapes, forms, tones, and textures of an image, sometimes color becomes a distraction. Other times, a color photograph can communicate things a black-and-white image cannot. Photographers and artists have long debated the merits of each approach. Here is a quote worth considering: “To see in color is a delight for the eye but to see in black and white is a delight for the soul.” – Andri Cauldwell

Want to take your portraits to the next level with lighting ratios?

You've come to the right place.

Because in this article, I'm going to share everything you need to know about lighting ratios for amazing portraits, including:

  • What lighting ratios are
  • Basic ratios for portrait photography
  • Tips for using ratios

(And much more!)

So if you want to become a portrait photography master, then let's get started.

What is a lighting ratio in photography?

As a math term, a ratio is a comparison of one thing to another.

So when calculating lighting ratios, you measure the light falling on the light or highlight side of the face and compare it to the light falling on the shadow side of the face.

For instance, if you have twice as much light falling on the highlight side of your portrait, then the lighting ratio would be 2:1. If you have four times as much light falling on the highlight side of your portrait, then the lighting ratio would be 4:1.

But how exactly do you measure light?

While you can do it with the built-in meter in your camera , it is much easier and more accurate to use a handheld incident light meter . You see, your in-camera meter takes a measurement of the light reflecting off your subject – whereas a handheld meter can measure the amount of light falling on your subject and therefore gives you a more accurate value.

Lighting ratios: key concepts

To properly measure and understand lighting ratios, you need to know a few things.

First, light is measured by f-stops . The aperture dial on your camera generally goes up in 1/3-stop increments, though the full stops for aperture are f/1, f/1.4, f/2, f/2.8, f/4, f/5.6, f/8, f/11, f/16, f/22, f/32, etc.

(A simple way to remember all the numbers is to memorize f/1 and f/1.4; all the other pairs are doubled from these with a few rounded off.)

You also need to understand that shutter speeds are also representative of f-stops, with the full stops at 1s, ½s, ¼s, 1/8s, 1/15s, 1/30s, 1/60s, 1/125s, 1/250s, 1/500s, 1/1000s, etc. Shutter speed full stops are easier to remember as they are generally doubled (with a couple instances of rounding, such as 1/8s to 1/15s).

Finally, know that each full stop is double (or half , depending on whether you go down or up) the amount of light compared to the previous one.

For example, if you are shooting at f/4 and want to shoot at f/5.6, you will need to double the amount of light to get an equivalent exposure (you'll need one more full stop of light). If you want to narrow your aperture by 2 stops, you'll need to add 2×2 – or 4 – times more light. Likewise, 3 stops correspond to 8 times more light (2x2x2) and so on.

Knowing this, you can figure out how to create and measure ratios. In the next series of photos, I will demonstrate four different lighting ratios and how they were achieved.

1:1 ratio

A 1:1 ratio is even lighting.

In other words, there is no difference in the meter readings on both sides of the face. As you can see in the photo above, 1:1 lighting is very flat, and it can be achieved in a couple of different ways.

First, you can use fill flash and make the flash equal to the main light source. This is harder to achieve until you've had some practice, and you'll often end up overpowering the light with flash.

Secondly, you could use a reflector . It will need to be very close to the subject, and the goal is to eliminate all shadows on the subject's face.

This is a 1:1 ratio, and it's pretty easy to see and recognize visually.

2:1 ratio

As the numbers suggest, a 2:1 ratio occurs when one side has twice as much light compared to the other.

So knowing that plus what you know about f-stops, we can set up this lighting ratio.

First, put your subject into the light where you are going to photograph them.

Using a light meter, measure the light falling on the side of their face closest to the light source (ie, the highlight side). Let's say that measures f/8. (Keep your shutter speed the same for all measurements to maintain consistency.)

Then bring in your reflector and use the light meter again, but this time measure the light falling on the side of the subject's face that is farther away from the light source (from here on in, this will be referred to as the shadow side ).

Note: If you are using a handheld meter, make sure to shield it from excess light that comes from the other side of your subject. So if you are metering the shadow side nearer the reflector, shield the meter so the main light source isn't hitting it.

Now, you know that your highlight side has a reading of f/8. To achieve a 2:1 lighting ratio, you'll need to get your meter to read f/5.6 (which is one stop less light) on the shadow side. So adjust the reflector distance until the meter settles on f/5.6.

Also, it may help to study the image above and recognize the contrast range from the highlight to the shadow side of the face. It's subtle, but you should be able to see it.

4:1 ratio

A 4:1 ratio is double a 2:1 ratio. So if 2:1 featured twice as much light – or one stop – how much light will a 4:1 ratio require?

The answer is four times as much light (2×2), which is a 2-stop difference from the highlight side to the shadow side of the face.

I teach an available light class, and I always recommend working with natural light before you advance on to speedlights . With available or natural light and a reflector, it is much easier to learn and practice lighting because you can see what happens as you make changes (WYSIWYG). Flash is harder to predict as you can't see it without actually taking a photograph.

So if our main light (the window) is still at f/8, what should be the value of our fill light/reflector (or the shadow side) to achieve a 4:1 ratio? Let's do the steps again: f/8>;f/5.6>;f/4.

Therefore, two stops less than f/8 is f/4 (and this is the desired measurement to create a 4:1 ratio). Look at the photo above and compare it to the 2:1 image; do you see how the shadow side is getting darker?

8:1 ratio

The last ratio we'll look at is 8:1.

The 8:1 ratio requires 8 times as much light, or 3 stops, on the highlight side of the face compared to the shadow side.

As you can see in the image above, 8:1 lighting is quite dramatic, and anything greater than 8:1 will not hold much detail on the shadow side of the face at all.

In fact, prints have a maximum contrast range of 4-6 stops, so unless you want one side of the face overexposed or the shadows pure black, I suggest keeping your lighting ratios at 8:1 or smaller.

Note that an 8:1 ratio can be a bit tough to create. You may need harsher lighting and possibly a black reflector to add blacks into the shadow side (rather than reflecting light onto it).

We calculate it the same way as above: if 4:1 is 4 times the light, then 8:1 will be 8 times the light, or 3 stops.

So if we are still at f/8 on our highlight side, we need to get our shadow side to read: f/8>;f/5.6>;f/4>;f/2.8.

How to use lighting ratios

Now that we have this knowledge of ratios, let's put it to use! Remember: The ratio can add to the success of your portrait, or it can ruin it.

If you look at the example images again, pay attention to how the mood of the image changes with the ratio. Notice how the higher ratios create more drama and power. Notice how the lower ratios are softer and more innocent.

Generally somewhere between 2:1 and 4:1 is the commonly used ratio for most portraiture. It's enough to create three-dimensionality on the face, but not too much to create unattractive, deep shadows. I personally like a 3:1 ratio (1.5 stops) or a 4:1 ratio, myself.

For a child or baby, you often want a lower ratio because the softer result goes well with the subject matter. But a grizzled old cowboy with weathered, wrinkled skin and unkempt whiskers looks much better with 4:1 or 8:1 lighting.为什么？ He's rougher, tougher, and can handle the increased contrast, plus it's suitable for his look.

If you're worried about not owning a handheld meter, you don't necessarily need to go out and buy one. I'd only suggest you do that if you plan on getting into studio lighting. Otherwise, just practice seeing the difference between the various ratios (which is why I suggest natural light), and if they aren't a perfect 4:1 or 8:1 or whatever, then it doesn't matter. Just learn to recognize when it's too strong and when it's too weak for the effect you want to create.

Lighting ratio tips

Now that you understand the lighting ratio basics, let's take a look at some quick tips that'll make your photos look better.

First, get your subject out of the sun . Shooting in bright sunlight makes it almost impossible to control your ratios, plus the light won't be desirable or flattering on the subject's face. Use natural light from a window with indirect lighting (no direct sun coming in) if you can. And if the sun is streaming in, try adding sheer curtains or even stretching a white bed sheet across to diffuse the light.

Second, here are some lighting ratio starting points:

  • For babies and small children, use a lower ratio like 1:1 or 2:1. Children move so quickly that keeping them in the light and facing in the right direction is exceedingly difficult, and even light helps mitigate this issue.
  • For women, use a medium ratio like 2:1 or 3:1.
  • For men and business portraits, use a slightly stronger ratio, such as 4:1 or 6:1.
  • For artists, bands, and other dramatic portraits, use a higher ratio.

Finally, keep in mind that there are no steadfast rules on how to do ratios in portraiture. Like everything in photography, it's about learning the techniques, then using them as suggestions while you experiment and find your own style or voice.

For instance, can you put 8:1 lighting on a glamorous movie star or 1:1 lighting on a coal miner? Absolutely!

(I'll even give you some homework that'll prove both ratios can be effective if they are done well.)

The moon is a wildly popular photography subject – it has a certain magic that captures nearly every photographer's imagination – but choosing the right moon photography settings can be quite tricky.

While it's definitely possible to capture sharp, well-exposed moon images, many beginner photographers don't use the right approach. As a result, they often just give up in frustration. That's where I can help .

You see, capturing great moon shots isn't too difficult once you wrap your head around a few basic elements. Just follow the camera settings advice I share below, and with a little patience and practice, you'll be taking excellent photos of the moon in no time at all.

Let's dive right in!

Moon photography settings: the basics

If you want a simple answer to the question of what moon photography settings to use, here's my advice:

  • Shoot with a fast shutter speed of at least 1/180s.
  • Use a small aperture like f/8.
  • Keep your ISO low – so that when you crop, your picture will remain clean and not noisy .
  • Use a telephoto lens .
  • Always shoot in RAW ; that way, you have plenty of room to edit the colors, sharpness, and other elements of your photo afterward.

Why these settings? Let me offer a short explanation:

The first thing to know about shooting the moon is that it's deceptively bright. You might not think of this giant ball of rock as particularly luminous when compared to the sun, but it puts out way more light than you might think. This makes it tricky to calculate exposure and get your other moon photography settings just right.

The other important item to keep in mind is that the moon is not a slow celestial body. In Greek mythology, Selene, the goddess of the moon, speeds across the night sky in a glowing chariot. Our ancient ancestors knew what they were talking about! If you take a picture of the moon, you have to keep its constant movement in mind; otherwise, you'll never get a great shot.

The final part of the equation to remember is that the moon, while relatively close in a galactic sense, is pretty far away when you look at it from the perspective of a photographer. If you want a good picture of the moon, you need at least a 200mm lens – and even then, it's best to use a crop-sensor camera for a bit more reach. So a focal length of 300mm or greater is recommended, and photographing the moon is one time when megapixels really do matter. Unless you have a very long zoom lens, you'll be cropping your images quite a bit.

While the above advice is a good starting point, you will need to experiment and figure out which settings are right for you. It's a good idea to dive a little deeper into aperture, shutter speed, and ISO – as well as different focal lengths, focusing modes, and file types – to find out what effect they have on your moon photos; that way, you can get the shots you're aiming for.

Choosing the perfect moon photography camera settings: 10 practical tips

好消息？ Choosing the right moon photo settings isn't rocket science. If you read the previous section, you already have a strong foundation – and below, I delve into all the key details, including the power of Manual mode, effective focusing techniques, and more.

1. Use Manual mode

This might be intimidating if you're used to letting your camera make exposure decisions for you, but moon photography is a great way to learn Manual mode .

Your camera knows what to do in most well-lit situations, but shooting the moon isn't one of them. You have to take control, and Manual mode lets you choose the aperture, shutter speed, and ISO – all of which are critical to getting good pictures of the moon. You must be very specific about your exposure settings, and Manual mode lets you dial in the precise values you need.

2. Shoot in RAW

You have enough to worry about when taking pictures of the moon: exposure settings, weather concerns, cloud cover, foreground obstructions…and that's just the beginning.

Setting the right white balance and making sure your highlights and shadows are perfectly captured is almost impossible to do in the moment. Thankfully, RAW can save the day.

Shooting in RAW gives you ultimate flexibility when editing your moon photos in a program such as Lightroom. You can adjust the exposure, tweak the sharpening, bring out details you might have missed, and of course, adjust the white balance to your heart's content.

The JPEG format is fine for many photographic situations, but not moon photography. For best results, use RAW.

3. Use a fast shutter speed

Shutter speed is a good place to start when thinking about moon photography settings because of how fast the moon moves across the sky. Similar to sports photography, you'll need a fast shutter speed to freeze the motion.

1/180s is a good starting point, but if you can go higher without increasing your ISO, I recommend doing so. 1/250s is good and so is 1/320s (go beyond that, and you start to get diminishing returns).

4. Keep your ISO low

Cameras have come a long way, and what used to be considered a crazy high ISO – like 3200 or 6400 – is now easily achieved without a huge loss in image quality. Things are a bit different when taking photos of the moon, though. Lower ISOs are always preferable, and that holds doubly true for photos of our nearest celestial neighbor.

ISO 100 or 200 is best, but that might not be realistic given the lens you're using. Generally speaking, you should be fine with ISO 800 or lower, partly because you will get a cleaner image, but also because you will have more leeway when editing your RAW files afterward.

5. Use a (reasonably) small aperture

Most lenses have what's known as a sweet spot , where the image isn't too soft and chromatic aberration is well-controlled. This sweet spot isn't usually at the widest or smallest aperture, but somewhere in the middle.

For that reason, I like to take pictures of the full moon at an aperture between f/4 and f/8. However, the optimal aperture will depend on your particular lens and the type of photos you're taking.

Honestly, of all the moon photography settings to worry about, I would put aperture at the bottom of my list. Before you consider the aperture, make sure you have a fast shutter speed and the lowest possible ISO. Finally, adjust your aperture until you get a picture you like.

Even if your photos are not tack-sharp because you had to shoot wide open, it's a trade-off I recommend making. I would rather have a slightly blurry result than a higher ISO setting that will result in noise, especially in the deep blacks of the night sky.

6. Work with a long lens

Let's get straight to it: you'll want a telephoto lens for your moon photography venture. With a longer focal length, you're not just photographing a tiny white circle in the sky; you're capturing craters, shadows, and all those mesmerizing details.

Starting at around 200mm can yield decent results, especially if you're using an APS-C camera, but I'd really aim for 300mm or even higher. A 400mm or 500mm lens is even better, and 600mm is better still. Assuming you use a sharp lens, the longer the focal length, the more detail you'll get in your shots, and the less you'll need to crop while editing.

But what if you don't have a long lens? Well, it's not the end of the world. Shorter lenses can work too, but you'll be sacrificing detail. Expect to spend more time cropping to make the moon the star of your shot (and expect reduced sharpness as a result of your crops).

Bottom line: whether you invest in a top-of-the-line lens or make do with what you have, the lens is a critical piece of the puzzle. Longer is generally better and will save you time and effort later on!

7. Underexpose slightly

It might seem counterintuitive, but when taking pictures of the moon, you don't want your images to be as bright as possible. I get my best results when underexposing by one stop or more, depending on the situation.

The easiest way to do this is to set your aperture, shutter speed, and ISO so your light meter indicates a properly exposed picture. Then drop the exposure by one or two stops. The result is a picture without any blown highlights and plenty of room for editing (as long as you make sure to shoot in RAW).

I also recommend using spot or center-weighted metering when doing moon photography. The moon is extraordinarily bright compared to the dark sky around it, which causes all sorts of confusion for your camera's light meter. Telling your camera to meter based on one small portion of the scene (ie the moon) will help you get a better initial exposure value, one that you can then fine-tune.

8. Get creative

Taking pictures of the moon is enthralling, especially if you have never done it before. But after a few shots of that big bright ball of light in the sky, start thinking of a new approach. Try putting trees, buildings, or other objects between you and the moon. Experiment with taking pictures during the waxing or waning crescent phase.

Also, try getting shots at dawn or dusk when you can catch the sky in a rich blue or purple. These are simple, fun ways of taking pictures of the moon that can produce some unexpected results.

9. Manually focus on the moon

Autofocus is convenient, but it often struggles when it comes to moon photography. That's when manual focus saves the day. This may seem daunting at first, but trust me, it's easier than you might think.

The goal here is to set your lens to focus at infinity. This is crucial because the moon is really, really far away. However, be careful. Turning your focus ring to the farthest point can sometimes go beyond infinity, making the moon blurry instead of sharp.

So, here's a pro tip: use your camera's LCD screen as a focusing aid. Magnify the moon on the LCD, and then adjust the manual focus ring. Keep tweaking until the moon's surface looks crisp.

Mastering manual focus might take a bit of practice, but it's worth it. Once you get the hang of it, you'll find it invaluable not just for moon photography but for other genres as well.

10. Tweak your results afterward

You've got your shot. Now what? Well, the truth is that capturing the moon is only part of the journey. Post-processing is where you bring your moon photograph to life, and you adjust tones and colors to complement your settings choices.

You'll likely need to add some sharpening and contrast, both of which will make those craters pop, revealing the moon in all its intricate detail. Software like Adobe Lightroom or Photoshop offers excellent tools for this! Also, remember that even a slight adjustment can make a world of difference.

But what about color? You might want to adjust the white balance for a natural result – and you can even make some temperature or tint tweaks for aesthetic reasons. Maybe you want a cooler image with bluish tones or perhaps a warmer look. The choice is yours, and color correction tools can help.

Last, don't forget about exposure. If your image is underexposed, you'll want to bring up the shadows or overall exposure to reveal lots of detail. And if the shot is overexposed, not all is lost. If you shot in RAW, you can likely recover some of those blown-out highlights!

Moon photography settings: final words

There's no magic or secret sauce when it comes to getting great shots of the moon. The only real trick is to get the right moon photography settings and to keep practicing until you're happy with the results.

And remember: The moon isn't going anywhere, and every lunar phase offers a new opportunity to perfect your skills. Missed a shot? There's always another night. Moon photography is an ongoing learning process, and the more you shoot, the better you'll get.

Try some of these settings as a starting point, and then branch out and see what you can come up with. You might be surprised at the pictures you're able to take!

Moon photography settings FAQ

Can I take a picture of the moon with my phone?

It's possible, but this is an area where a DSLR or mirrorless camera with full manual controls really has the edge. A mobile phone can't zoom in very far, and even those that do have optical zoom lack the light-gathering ability required for good moon shots. That's not to say it can't be done, but you'll likely get significantly better results with a dedicated camera.

Do I need an expensive zoom lens to get a picture of the moon?

A zoom lens helps, but it doesn't have to be expensive. Even a basic 55-250mm kit lens , like the one that might have come with your camera when you bought it, is fine. Just make sure to follow some of the tips in this article, and you can get some good moon pictures.

What white balance setting should I use to get a picture of the moon?

That really depends, and there's not always a good answer. Some people like to use the Daylight setting because the moon is reflecting the sunlight and has no actual light of its own. Just make sure you shoot in RAW so you can adjust your white balance after you take the picture.

How do I keep both the moon and the foreground in focus?

First, make sure you are using a small aperture like f/8 or f/11, which will give a much wider depth of field . In addition, you need to put a lot of space between you and your foreground objects. If you're shooting through tree branches in your own backyard, they will always end up far too blurry. Position yourself so the trees, buildings, or other foreground objects are farther away; this will help make sure they are more in focus.

How do I get the moon to look so big? My moon pictures never look like the professional shots I see online.

Many people have asked me this, and it all comes down to your lens. A longer focal length will make the moon appear larger. If you don't have a long lens, you can rent one for the few days that a bright full moon is visible. Many professional moon pictures are also cropped, and if you use a very high megapixel camera, you have a great deal of freedom to crop without a huge drop in quality.

尽管我很喜欢拍照的行为，但编辑却拖慢了我的速度，削弱了我的灵感，并将这种极具创意的努力变成了一件我偶尔会感到厌恶的苦差事。简而言之，我宁愿在外地与客户会面，也不愿坐在电脑前点击按钮和滑块。然而，在进行人像摄影时，你不能真正做到两者缺一不可——直到现在。

Lightroom 的全新人工智能工具可以显着加快编辑过程，并且通过正确的方法，您可以获得非常令人印象深刻的结果。换句话说，Lightroom AI 工具为您提供了两全其美的功能，因此编辑肖像几乎与拍摄肖像一样有趣。

下面，我将深入研究 Lightroom 提供的 AI 功能。我解释它们是什么以及它们如何增强您的编辑工作流程，然后我以一个分步示例作为结束语，以便您可以准确理解我的意思（以及如何对自己的照片执行相同操作！）。

Lightroom 的 AI 工具有哪些？

人工智能正在迅速融入现代摄影的几乎每个元素。手机使用人工智能计算曝光，创建精美的 HDR 图像，即使在弱光下也能拍摄不模糊的照片。 Luminar 和其他编辑程序利用 AI 来消除瑕疵、替换天空和重塑脸部。 Photoshop 正在以一种允许任何人从无到有地创建对象和艺术品的方式拥抱生成式人工智能 - 只需使用几个描述性关键字。

Lightroom 的做法略有不同。它使用人工智能本身并不是一种编辑工具；相反，它将人工智能的力量置于您的手中，使您的编辑变得更容易、更有效。 Lightroom 不会使用 AI 来使皮肤更光滑或牙齿更白，但 Lightroom 的 AI 将帮助您使皮肤更光滑和牙齿更白，并且它会帮助您同时处理大量照片。

这似乎好得令人难以置信。使用 Lightroom 的 AI 工具修饰肖像后，您将不想再回到旧的编辑方式。

使用 Lightroom 的 AI 工具加快编辑速度

我喜欢为客户拍照。与他们见面，在会议期间了解他们，并找到创造性的方法来捕捉永恒的图像，这些图像将与他人分享或打印和装框给后代，这是非常有趣的。

我不喜欢的是拍照结束后在 Lightroom 中度过的日子，仔细研究数百张照片，以便找到并编辑最好的照片。虽然 Lightroom 的 AI 工具无法加快剔除过程（尽管如果这种情况在不久的将来发生，我不会感到惊讶！），但它们可以将复杂编辑任务的时间缩短到几分钟。

所有这一切的关键是Lightroom 的 AI 支持的遮罩选项，以及同时在多个图像上同步遮罩的能力。 Lightroom 使用人工智能模型来识别和掩盖牙齿、嘴唇和头发等面部特征。该程序甚至可以遮盖眼睛的各个部分，例如虹膜和巩膜（即虹膜周围的白色元素）。然后，您可以对任何或所有人工智能创建的蒙版进行编辑，与传统的手动蒙版和编辑方法相比，这本身就确保了速度的大幅提高。

你看，在Lightroom的AI遮罩工具推出之前，所有这些工作都必须手工完成。我记得使用Lightroom 画笔工具逐一仔细选择肖像元素 - 在一张图像上完成所有工作后，我必须在下一张图像上重新开始，因为编辑从来没有完全一致照片到下一张。

这个过程使编辑变得极其缓慢，甚至导致一些摄影师将编辑工作外包给第三方，付钱给其他人编辑图像，这样他们就不必这样做。但现在，有了 Lightroom 的 AI 工具，这一切都可以在几秒钟内完成。

如何使用 Lightroom 的 AI 工具加速肖像编辑：分步示例

说明 Lightroom 的 AI 工具如何在编辑过程中节省大量时间的最佳方法是分享一个真实肖像会话的示例。我和一个年轻人在湖边度过了一个小时，同时拍摄他高中毕业的肖像，我们聊天、散步、寻找绝佳的拍照机会，度过了一段美妙的时光。

他高兴地摆着姿势，微笑着，从一个地方走到另一个地方，而我拍了数百张照片。这是轻松愉快的，我们为他拍了一些出色的照片，送给年鉴顾问并与他的朋友们分享。

然后，由于 Lightroom 和人工智能的结合，后期处理变得轻而易举。让我解释一下如何：

第 1 步：创建 AI 蒙版

因此，一些编辑，例如曝光和白平衡，根本不需要人工智能；使用Lightroom 开发模块中的“同步”按钮，可以快速轻松地将一张照片同步到许多其他照片。

然而，其他编辑可以受益于一些人工智能驱动的遮蔽。首先，选择“修改照片”模块中的“遮罩”选项，然后等待 Lightroom 检测到人物。接下来，单击人物（通常标记为“人物 1”，除非照片中有多个人物）并选择要创建的蒙版。您可以从面部皮肤、眉毛、牙齿、头发甚至衣服等选项中进行选择：

第 2 步：编辑 AI 蒙版

创建 AI 蒙版后，将出现一个弹出面板，其中包含一些基本信息。您可以单击面板并将其拖动到屏幕的另一部分，和/或您可以使用右上角的 >;>; 符号将其折叠，使其变小且不碍事。蒙版的默认标题只是“蒙版 1”，但您可以单击三点图标来更改其名称，还可以通过单击眼睛图标来显示和隐藏蒙版。

您可以使用相应调整面板中的滑块修改曝光、高光、阴影、颜色、锐度等参数。在这种情况下，我只想美白拍摄对象的牙齿，所以我选择“牙齿美白”预设。它做得很好（尽管我确实对白平衡做了一些调整）。

第 3 步：添加另一个蒙版

肖像编辑很少涉及仅使用一个蒙版，Lightroom 的 AI 驱动工具可以再次为您提供帮助。单击“蒙版”弹出面板顶部的“创建新蒙版”按钮，然后选择“选择人物”选项；这将让您再次选择人物的各个元素。

在本例中，我为年轻人的面部皮肤创建了一个蒙版，您可以看到人工智能驱动的蒙版工具准确地选择了图像的正确部分。如果我手动完成这种选择，那么我会花费更长的时间——它需要使用画笔工具进行大量精确的工作——但 Lightroom 只用了不到一秒就完成了。

创建第二个蒙版后，您可以重复上一步中讨论的相同过程；只需单击蒙版，然后使用右侧的滑块进行调整即可。

我应用了皮肤平滑预设，使年轻人的脸变得更光滑一些。请注意，不要太多——一系列微妙的编辑通常更有效——但足以引人注目。

我发现此时为每个蒙版命名很有帮助，当蒙版稍后与其他照片同步时，该名称会派上用场。如果它们简单地称为“Mask 1”、“Mask 2”等，则很难确切地知道它们是什么以及您正在同步什么。

步骤 4：根据需要重复

根据需要重复此过程，并对需要进行一些调整的功能进行编辑。您最终可能会得到十几个面具，或者可能只使用几个；无论哪种方式，这些人工智能屏蔽工具的好处很快就会变得显而易见。

正如您所看到的，这个过程结合了人工智能和手动干预，结果与我自己创建所有蒙版一样好，而且速度肯定要快得多。 Lightroom 实际上并没有为我编辑任何内容，并且在此过程中的任何时候您都不会放弃对程序的编辑控制。相反，Lightroom 使用 AI 来提高您自己的编辑过程的速度和灵活性。因此，您的工作流程可以显着加快。

第 5 步：同步您的编辑

这就是乐趣的开始。在过去，您可能会花费宝贵的时间仔细研究单张图像，手动创建蒙版并调整它们以使一切都恰到好处，结果却必须为每张额外的照片重新进行一遍。幸运的是，那些日子已经一去不复返了，如果你是一名肖像摄影师，你的生活将永远不会一样。

使用“修改照片”面板底部的幻灯片选择您刚刚编辑的图像。然后按住 Shift 或 Ctrl 键并选择要应用编辑的所有图像。您可以选择一张图像、一百张图像或根据需要选择任意数量的图像。

单击右下角的同步...按钮。然后，出现提示时，选择要同步的蒙版。

注意：这一步在 mask 命名的时候就派上用场了。如果您花时间为每个蒙版提供描述性名称，您就会准确地知道您正在同步的内容 - 这有助于确保 Lightroom 完全按照您的要求进行操作，仅此而已。

准备就绪后，单击“同步”按钮并观看奇迹的发生。

Lightroom 现在使用人工智能为您选择同步的所有图像创建新蒙版。然后，程序对新图像应用与原始图像相同的编辑。

该过程可能需要一两分钟，具体取决于计算机的速度，但在我早期的图像编辑过程中可能需要几个小时。操作完成后，您可以在任何图像上编辑单独的蒙版，甚至可以将这些新编辑同步到其他图像。

购买新相机装备时要避免的 10 个错误一文首先出现在数码摄影学校上。它的作者是德斯汀·斯帕克斯。

购买新相机、镜头、三脚架或照片配件？对于任何摄影师来说，寻找装备的阶段都是令人兴奋的时刻，但它也可能令人生畏，特别是如果您计划在下次购买时花费数百甚至数千美元。您想要做出正确的决定，但考虑到众多的选择，您很容易感到不知所措。

幸运的是，我自己购买了相当多的相机设备，并且一路上我发现了很多设备购买的陷阱。在本文中，我讨论了购买新设备时要避免的 10 个最严重的错误；这样，您就可以阻止自己做出令人沮丧的决定，而这些决定最终会花费您的时间、精力和金钱。

Let's dive right in!

1.听取错误的人的建议

在最终做出重大购买决定之前征求其他人的建议是正常的，甚至是明智的。然而，从正确的来源获取建议很重要。不要只是听那些听起来好像他们知道自己在说什么的人说的话；相反，确保他们确实了解电子取景器和电子前帘快门。

因此，一旦您找到了一位潜在的顾问，请问问自己：这个人真的是专家吗？他们是真正了解相机的人吗？他们是否真的了解与我所购买的商品相关的所有功能？他们是否足够了解这些功能以提出明智的意见？

如果你不能自信地说“是！”回答完这些问题后，您可能需要联系其他人。因为虽然有很多摄影师对相机设备略知一二，但您必须与能够了解您的独特需求以及您的需求与他们的需求不同的许多方面的人交谈。

与此相关的是，避免仅仅因为您认识的摄影师拥有它或因为所有在线评论都说它是市场上最好的装备而购买任何东西。向值得信赖的专家提出问题，即使如此，也不要将他们的想法当作福音；相反，请将建议作为帮助您做出决定的重要工具。请记住：即使是最好的建议也不能替代研究和仔细比较购物。

2.忘记检查兼容性

您可能认为所有相机设备都可以很好地配合。不幸的是，事实并非如此。曾经尝试过将尼康镜头安装到佳能机身上吗？这就像试图将方钉装入圆孔中一样。甚至不让我开始使用第三方设备。虽然第三方公司经常为多个相机品牌提供镜头型号，但您必须购买合适的型号；否则，您收到的镜头将毫无用处。

APS-C 镜头是另一个很好的例子。它们可能与您的全画幅相机来自同一品牌，但将它们配对在一起就会带来麻烦。这些镜头是为较小的传感器设计的，因此如果将它们安装在全画幅相机上，要么会出现暗角，要么镜头根本无法工作。

存储卡也很难使用。它们可能看起来很合适，但许多存储卡的设计都是相同的，而且外观可能具有欺骗性！闪光灯和遥控器等配件也同样挑剔。有时它们是针对特定品牌的；其他时候，它们是特定于模型的。

最后，考虑电池；在这里，使用不兼容的产品不仅仅会导致相机无法供电。他们实际上可以损坏它。

那么如何避免这些陷阱呢？始终做好你的研究。不要只看产品列表或在线规格。潜入深处。检查评论，在论坛中提问，如果其他方法都失败，请咨询制造商的网站。现在多花几分钟可以让你免于日后的伤害，尤其是在无法返回的情况下。

3. 假设成本等于质量

是的，高质量的装备应该被视为一种投资，如果您是一名专业摄影师（或者您打算成为一名专业摄影师），您通常需要花费数千美元来创建基本设置。然而，重要的是，您不要简单地认为更高的价格标签自动意味着您可以获得更好的商品。

即使钱对您来说不是问题，一些高质量的设备实际上比低质量的设备成本更低，特别是如果您购买第三方。此外，支付更多费用并不能保证您购买的产品能够真正满足您的需求。由于具有数十种令人印象深刻的功能，相机可能会花费更多，但如果这些功能对您来说毫无价值，那么它真的值得购买吗？

昂贵的相机也不能保证您拍出梦寐以求的精彩照片，因为最好的摄影设备的好坏取决于实际拍照的人。

我的建议是：少关注价格标签，多关注给定的商品是否适合您。问问自己：这个装备适合我目前的技能水平吗？我熟悉所有的功能和工具吗？它适合我的摄影类型吗？

归根结底，如果您不使用它们或不理解它们，那么数十种附加功能和许多不同的设置对您没有任何好处！

4. 购买“炒作”产品而不进行研究

每年，都会有一些产品承诺以革命性的新效果改变您的摄影。但是，虽然这些“炒作”产品（例如具有迷人聚焦效果的镜头或通用配件）看起来很诱人，但重要的是退后一步，确保您知道自己要做什么。

其中一些产品确实提供了新颖的体验，甚至可以向您介绍以前从未尝试过的摄影风格。但重要的是要问自己：我实际上会使用该产品多少？柔焦镜头在最初几天可能会很有趣，但很快就会失去吸引力。

其他炒作产品简直就是糟糕透顶。曾经看过超紧凑型三脚架吗？虽然这些产品通常承诺兼具稳定性和便携性，但许多产品却忽略了基本功能。您可能会发现三脚架摇晃或缺乏所需的高度和头部运动。然后还有创意过滤器。他们可能承诺让您的照片看起来很华丽，但有些可能会降低图像质量。

那么解决办法是什么呢？在购买之前花时间认真考虑每种产品。寻找公正的评论，最好是那些展示现实世界例子的评论。问问自己：我真的打算长期使用该产品吗？如果它放在抽屉里，它可能不值你的钱。并始终权衡利弊。有时，产品的局限性会破坏交易；其他时候它们只是小烦恼。

5. 未能正确制定预算

在生活中，适当的计划往往是成功的关键，购买摄影器材也不例外。规划阶段的很大一部分涉及预算，在这方面您可能会犯一些常见的错误。

其一，许多购物者没有考虑配件的全部成本。例如，良好的风景摄影设置需要一台高质量的相机，但它还需要多个镜头、电池、 三脚架、存储卡等。人们很容易把注意力集中在相机和/或镜头上，然后在购买（仍然必不可少的）三脚架、存储卡等之前就花光了钱。

因此，在您购买任何新装备之前，我建议您列出您可能需要的所有物品的清单，并准确确定整个设置的成本。

6. 购买多余的装备

您已经关注了新相机、镜头或配件，并且确信它会将您的摄影提升到新的高度。我当然知道这种感觉 - 但在购买之前，请确保您还没有拥有已经可以达到您想要的结果的装备。

假设您有一个 50mm f/1.8 镜头。它坚固、可靠，并且能拍出很棒的照片。但随后你会看到一个 50mm f/1.4 镜头。当然，它更快，但真正的问题是，你会注意到其中的区别吗？额外的费用值得吗？通常，答案是否定的。

变焦镜头也是如此。如果您有优质的 24-70mm 变焦镜头，那么购买 16-35mm 似乎是个好主意。但想一想。您多久以这些广角进行拍摄？有时，摄影师比镜头更重要。如果您知道如何构图，您就可以利用已有的东西。

在进行任何新购买之前，请先查看您现有的装备。列出每个项目的优点和不足之处。如果确实存在差距，那么无论如何都要填补它。但如果您只是要加倍能力，请三思而后行。有时，少即是多。

7. 因特价商品而分心

您终于准备好走进摄影店并进行购买了。你已经完成了你的作业。您已经确定哪种相机适合您的要求。您甚至还挑选了与之配套的配件和其他工具。你很清楚自己想要什么。

然后你走进商店，你会看到十几个标牌，上面写着大量装备的特价广告！很容易失去注意力，但我恳求你：记住你来这里的目的！

切勿仅仅因为任何摄影器材展示在华丽的标志下或因为销售人员坚持认为这是您绝对必须拥有的而购买任何摄影器材。如果某件事听起来好得令人难以置信，那么它可能就是真的。密切关注奖品，并确保带着您真正需要的装备走出商店。

8.购买低质量的预算产品

正如我在上一篇技巧中讨论的那样，我们都喜欢划算的交易。还有一些非常诱人的产品承诺以无与伦比的价格提供令人难以置信的质量。

现在，确实成本并不等于质量。有很多价格低廉的优秀产品。另一方面，一些廉价产品根本就很便宜，如果你不小心，你最终会花光所有的钱却一无所获。

以第三方镜头为例。 Tamron、Sigma 和 Tokina 等品牌生产了一些相当出色的产品。但并非所有预算镜头都是一样的。在低成本领域冒险太远，您将开始看到质量明显下降。图像看起来会模糊，或者构建质量不合格。不知不觉中，你又回到了原点，只是现在你已经花掉了五十美元。

过滤器也可能是一个陷阱。您可能会在 eBay 上找到价值 15 美元的 ND 滤镜，并认为自己中了大奖。但一分钱一分货。廉价的滤镜实际上会降低图像质量，使一张好照片变得不那么好。

再次强调，一定要做好功课。阅读评论、比较产品并考虑您的需求。在点击“购买”按钮之前，请确保低成本选项确实值得。相信我：未来的你会感谢你。

9. 超越自己

我们大多数人都有远大的摄影梦想，希望有一天能够实现。也许您想成为一名专业的旅行摄影师，您会想象自己拖着一袋相机装备从一个地点飞到另一个地点。也许您希望成为《体育画报》的下一位专业篮球摄影师，并想象自己拥有一台坚固耐用的相机、六个超长焦镜头和一个坚固的独脚架。

虽然这些梦想很伟大，而且是让你保持动力的绝佳方式，但在你投入大量资金购买专业级装备之前，问问自己这些梦想是否有可能在不久的将来实现，这一点很重要。

例如，如果您是摄影新手，您可能不应该花费 4000 美元以上购买相机，即使它是专业旅行摄影师使用的最流行的型号。如果您只用 iPhone 拍照，那么您可能不应该花费超过 8000 美元购买令人难以置信的超远摄镜头。

基本上，不要太过超前。有梦想是件好事，但要根据您当前的需求和技能水平进行购物，而不是根据您对未来某一天的期望。看起来可能并非如此，但迎合您当前的技能将使您更有可能对现在和将来的购买感到满意。

10.投资装备而不是教育

最后但并非最不重要的一点是，让我们谈谈购买装备作为快速解决方案的冲动。我们都去过那里。我们看到一张令人惊叹的照片并想：“如果我有那个镜头，我也能做到这一点。”但事情是这样的：装备只是一个工具。它无法弥补技能的不足。

摄影不仅仅是精美的相机或镜头。您需要了解灯光、设置和构图。如果你不这样做，即使是最好的装备也无法帮助你。如何利用你所拥有的东西才是真正重要的。

那么除了花钱购买新装备之外，你应该怎么做呢？考虑投资教育。从现场研讨会到在线课程，有很多方法可以提高您的摄影水平。如果您预算紧张，您甚至可以找到免费资源。 （只需查看 dPS 提供的所有深入文章即可！）

在你用信用卡购买另一个镜头之前，问问自己：这笔钱花在可以提升我未来所有照片质量的课程或研讨会上是否更好？通常，答案是肯定的。投资于学习可以提供持续一生的回报，即使在新装备的气味消失很久之后。

购买相机装备时的错误：最后的话

我们终于得到它了。如果您已经做到了这一步，请拍拍自己的背。您现在掌握的知识不仅可以为您节省金钱，还可以减少很多挫败感。成为一名熟练摄影师的道路不仅仅取决于包里的硬件；还取决于您的相机。这是关于在每一步中做出明智的选择。

新镜头或最先进相机的诱惑是不可抗拒的。但知道要避免什么和知道要买什么一样有价值。

所以请记住我分享的建议。请务必考虑您的预算，确定您当前的需求，无论您做什么，都不要因销售和讨价还价而分心！

这样，您就可以获得最适合您的摄影天赋的装备。

因此，如果您准备好拍摄一些令人难以置信的照片，那么让我们从我们的第一个想法开始吧：

1.玩转灯光

第一个：光。毕竟，这就是摄影的本质。但你是否充分挖掘了它的潜力？光的用途极其广泛，为艺术诠释提供了无限的机会。

让我们谈谈您的选择。您可以选择透过窗户的自然光。它是免费的、丰富的，并且可以根据一天中的时间和角度创造出令人惊叹的高调或低调效果。 LED 灯泡或灯等人造光也可以改变游戏规则。这些允许您控制强度和方向，为您的镜头添加细微差别。

工作室灯也非常适合实验。即使您没有一套闪光灯，单个闪光灯也可以创造奇迹。就像画家在画布上添加大胆的笔触一样，您可以使用工作室灯光来塑造您的摄影视觉。利用角度来突出某些区域或创建有趣的阴影。

沿着太阳的方向拍摄以创造艺术镜头光晕怎么样？这可以给图像增添一种空灵的品质。将光源放置在拍摄对象后面也可以产生美丽的轮廓，在不透露细节的情况下表达丰富的内容。

并且不要忘记长时间曝光。您是否尝试过长时间拍摄窗户？这项技术使光线看起来像是从玻璃发出的。将平凡的事物变成艺术品，这几乎是神奇的。

2.拍摄水滴

水滴摄影确实需要一些专门的设备 - 但结果非常华丽，你实际上可以花数年时间捕捉不同的水滴类型、背景、颜色等。

另外，一旦您了解了基本设置，就可以相对容易地获得如下所示的图像：

首先，您需要一台带有微距镜头（或具有强大的特写功能）的相机。您还需要一个三脚架（用于将相机固定到位）、一个离机闪光灯（用于照亮水滴）、一个滴管和一碗水。

这个想法是将相机放置在水碗旁边。将镜头切换为手动对焦，然后预对焦在碗的中间（水会落下的地方）。

高举滴水器，在碗上滴几滴水，当它们接近水面时，启动相机。

请注意，水滴摄影将涉及大量的试验和错误，特别是如果您使用我上面描述的简单 DIY 设置。为了使您的水滴照片更加一致，您可以购买专门的水滴器和装备（尽管这些可能会很昂贵，所以如果您认真对待这种形式的摄影，我只建议您走这样的路线！）

3. 使用彩色反光板

步入色彩领域可能会带来变革性的体验。当然，人造灯上的彩色凝胶有其用武之地，但是您尝试过使用彩色反射器吗？它们更加微妙并且非常容易实现，尤其是当您在家拍摄时。

反光板的美妙之处在于它们不仅仅适合专业人士。您可以自己制作，而无需花很多钱。只需前往工艺品店购买彩色海报板或反光织物即可开始。获得材料后，将它们切成可管理的尺寸，然后就可以开始了。

现在到了有趣的部分——实验。将蓝色、绿色、黄色、红色或橙色反光板放在靠近拍摄对象的位置。反射到拍摄对象上的最终色调会根据您选择的颜色而有所不同。这就像用光绘画，但更字面意义上的。

多个反射器可以放大效果。从不同角度使用它们，将您的拍摄对象包裹在色彩的茧中。结果可以是从戏剧性的喜怒无常到空灵柔和的任何东西，具体取决于您选择的颜色和角度。

听说过色轮吗？它在这里可能是一个有用的工具。将红色和绿色等相反的颜色搭配起来，让你的主题更加流行。或者使用类似的颜色，即方向盘上彼此接近的颜色，以获得和谐、宁静的外观。相信我，你的创造力将会飙升。

4.拍摄一些食物

每个人都喜欢练习食物摄影，尤其是当食物看起来很棒的时候。这种类型的范围很广（如果您可以将食物照片作为库存出售，则可能会有利可图）。

要在舒适的家中开始美食摄影，请遵循以下指南：

  • 照明是关键。窗户侧光等自然光效果很好。如果您使用离机闪光灯，光线应来自食物后面，但一定要将光线反射回来（即使用反光板），以避免照片中出现不必要的阴影。
  • 注意背景。标准静物背景（例如纯白色灯箱）可能会很有效。但您也可以享受带纹理的背景的乐趣，例如织物或彩绘画布。不要随意选择背景；确保它为您想要拍摄的食物添加背景！
  • 仔细设计你的食物。最好的专业美食摄影师会聘请美食造型师，但我们其他人却没有那么奢侈。相反，你必须仔细地将你的食物安排成美丽的构图（你可以享受有趣的实验，但我经常喜欢使用重复元素，例如下面的草莓镜头）。

5. 做一些镜头光绘

Lensball提供了一种简单的方法来捕捉华丽的折射照片 - 但如果您想将 Lensball 照片提升到一个新的水平，为什么不尝试 Lensball 光绘，只需一些基本物品即可在室内完成呢？

您需要一个黑暗的房间，所以要么在晚上拍摄，要么在零窗户的地下室或浴室里拍摄。您还需要一个三脚架来固定相机，以及一张桌子和一块玻璃来固定镜头球。

将玻璃片放在桌子上，然后小心地将镜头球放在玻璃片上。 （我喜欢在球下面使用钥匙圈来防止它滚动，我稍后将其编辑掉。）

设置相机，使其聚焦在镜头球上，关闭灯光，然后将快门速度设置为五秒或更长。

然后，一旦按下快门按钮，就用手电筒在房间里走动。享受在空中绘制不同图案的乐趣（正如您在下面的照片中看到的，之字形总是很有趣！）。不必太死板；模式越狂野，结果就越有趣。

6.创作经典静物布置

静物摄影流传已久是有原因的——它是永恒的。你不需要一个装满道具的工作室；看看你的房子周围。您通常忽视的物体可能会成为您艺术创作中的明星。

想想旧手表、质朴的厨具，甚至一串葡萄。将它们以视觉上令人愉悦的方式排列在桌子或台面上。现在，是时候点亮您的设置了。如果附近有窗户，自然光会产生奇妙的效果。柔和的漫射光可以给你的静物画带来绘画般的品质。

如果无法选择自然光，则可以使用工作室灯光。调整它们以突出显示构图的关键区域或创建深度阴影。光的质量可以极大地改变情绪。例如，硬光可以给你的静物画带来现代感，而软光则可以让它感觉经典和永恒。

不要犹豫，尽情玩耍吧。旋转你的物体，尝试不同的背景，甚至可以添加一些反光表面以获得额外的光泽。你是这个静态场景的艺术家、导演。您对布置和灯光的选择创造了您想要讲述的故事。

背景同样重要。木质表面可能会带来质朴的魅力，而光滑的黑色或白色背景可以让您的物品脱颖而出。甚至光线的方向也能营造气氛，让你的布置感觉平静、戏剧性或神秘。

7. 拍摄冰冻物体

如果你被困在家里几天，为什么不尝试一些冷冻物体摄影呢？它会给你独特的照片，就像这样：

首先，在一个容器中装满一英寸的水，将其放入冰箱中，然后等待一天。

接下来，找一些有趣的物品，比如食物、鲜花，甚至玩具。将它们放在冰盖上，添加更多的水（直到覆盖它们），然后将容器放入冰箱中，再等待一天左右。

此时，您可以添加更多的水并再等待一天 - 这取决于冰的厚度和您想要的外观 - 或者您可以从容器中取出冰并开始拍摄。我建议从不同的方向照亮你的拍摄对象（你甚至可以尝试使用背光以获得凉爽、空灵的效果）。

有没有想过那些光鲜亮丽的杂志广告如何让日常产品看起来如此吸引人？那么，您可以在家里重现这种魔力。四处走走，挑选一些您喜欢的产品。它可以是任何东西——一瓶香水、一件闪亮的厨房用具，甚至是一双时髦的鞋子。

像品牌大使一样思考一下。如何让这些产品看起来令人难以抗拒？尝试展示产品最佳功能的各种概念。也许您想捕捉智能手机的时尚设计或您最喜欢的零食包装的鲜艳色彩。

网络共享设置是您最好的朋友。它可以让您立即在更大的屏幕上查看照片。这样，您就可以实时调整以获得完美的镜头。网络共享可以消除猜测，并避免您在后期处理过程中出现令人不快的意外情况。

质量很重要，因此请确保您拍摄的产品干净且处于一流状态。拍摄后，请毫不犹豫地修饰图像。一点点修饰可以大大增强产品照片的视觉吸引力。

请记住，这个练习不仅仅是为了好玩；而是为了好玩。它可以提高您的商业摄影技巧。品牌为此类工作付出了大笔费用。那么谁知道呢？你可能只是在建立一个可以在未来为你带来一些演出的投资组合。

寻找与您的主题相得益彰的背景。它可以是一张彩色床单、一张木桌，甚至是一张手工纸质景观。重点是创造一个让这些微型角色栩栩如生的世界。

微距镜头是您的秘密武器。有了它，您可以放大复杂的细节，使玩具在照片中呈现真人大小。密切对焦可以揭示经常被忽视的纹理和微妙之处。

风景摄影的最佳 ISO（指南和技巧）一文首先出现在数码摄影学校上。 It was authored by Christian Hoiberg .

Choosing the best ISO for landscape photography is hard , especially as a beginner. Should you use a low ISO for a clean image? Or should you use a high ISO to keep things sharp? Or go with something in between?

Fortunately, while picking the perfect ISO is often intimidating, there are some simple tips you can use to get the ISO consistently right.

And that's what this article is all about. I'm going to share with you my ISO recommendations. By the time you're finished, picking the ideal landscape photography ISO will be a piece of cake – so your images can stay sharp, beautiful, and noise-free .

Let's dive right in.

The problem with ISO in landscape photography

First, let's delve into why picking an ISO while photographing landscapes can be such a puzzle.

The ideal settings for capturing expansive vistas often involve narrow apertures, like f/11 or f/16. These settings make sure more of your scene is in focus, but they also let less light hit your camera's sensor.

And when photographing during those golden hours – sunrise and sunset – or during twilight and night, even less light hits the camera sensor. As a result, your images will turn out very underexposed, unless you make significant adjustments to your aperture, shutter speed, or ISO.

Opening up your aperture will brighten the exposure, but it comes with a cost: The depth of field (ie, the area of sharp focus) narrows, potentially blurring key elements of your scene. Slowing down the shutter speed can also brighten your image, but it risks introducing motion blur, especially if the scene includes moving elements (such as tree leaves waving in the wind). Not to mention, if you're handholding your camera, a slow shutter speed is a surefire way to get blur due to camera shake.

Finally, you have a third option: boosting the ISO. Raise the ISO, and your camera amplifies the sensor signal, making your picture brighter. But here's the catch: higher ISO levels create noise, the tiny speckles of light and color that degrade image quality.

So you find yourself at a crossroads. Do you sacrifice some depth of field by widening your aperture? Do you risk motion blur by choosing a longer shutter speed? Or do you increase your ISO and cope with the inevitable noise? It's a tough call, and below, I share my advice, starting with my number one rule:

The best ISO for landscape photography is always the lowest ISO you can get away with

Picking the right ISO is a balancing act.

A higher ISO lets you use a fast shutter speed so you can take sharper images in low light. And it also boosts image brightness so you get plenty of detail in dark scenarios.

But a higher ISO also reveals unwanted noise in your images, which looks really, really bad. Noise is something you want to avoid, and it's the reason that you'll often hear things like, “The best ISO for landscape photography is always 100.”

When I first started out as a landscape photographer, that's what I believed. I used ISO 100 all the time (except for night photography).

Now, I still think you should use ISO 100 for most stationary landscapes. But you shouldn't make the mistake of only using that setting. It took me several years before I accepted that there's no one correct ISO in landscape photography.

Instead of always dialing in ISO 100, pick the lowest ISO you can afford while getting the effect and level of sharpness you're after. This is often ISO 100, but it isn't always; sometimes, you need to boost your ISO setting to ensure the best possible image quality.

When does ISO 100 fail?

Here are some common scenarios when you might need to bump up the ISO beyond 100:

  • 手持拍摄时
  • When trying to freeze moving subjects
  • When photographing at night

But those are just a few of the scenarios where ISO 100 might not be possible. There are also less obvious times you'll want to increase the ISO:

  • When adjusting the shutter speed to capture perfect motion/flow in water
  • If you need to freeze elements moving in the wind (such as bushes, branches, etc.)

So to reiterate my advice in the previous section:

Pick the lowest ISO possible, but bear in mind that you may need to keep it above ISO 100 in certain scenarios, as I explore in greater detail below.

Tips for choosing the best landscape photography ISO

Choosing the right ISO is far from easy. Below, I offer tips and tricks so you can capture landscape photos like the pros.

1. Boost the ISO at night for a faster shutter speed

As you now know, ISO 100 is not ideal for night photography . So what ISO is best for shooting at night?

Well, at night there's not a lot of light. You need a lengthy shutter speed to capture a well-exposed image.

But you can't just lengthen the shutter speed and expect a great result. For instance, setting the shutter speed to 30 seconds and leaving the ISO at 100 will still result in an underexposed image. And if you set the shutter speed to 10 minutes and leave the ISO at 100, you'll end up with partial star trails – sometimes this can be a nice effect, but it often isn't the goal.

So instead of lengthening the shutter speed, you need to sacrifice some image cleanliness and increase the ISO.

In other words, when choosing the best ISO for landscape photography at night, you'll first need to pick a long shutter speed (often in the 10-second to 30-second range). And then you'll need to boost the ISO – so you can capture beautiful, detailed, well-exposed shots.

The exact ISO you need depends on the moon phase and the overall brightness of your scene. For instance, being close to city lights or other light sources will reduce the required ISO.

When shooting at night, I first set my aperture and shutter speed. Then I dial in my base ISO for night photography, ISO 1600.

But just as with ISO 100, ISO 1600 isn't the only night landscape photography ISO you should use. Instead, ISO 1600 works as a starting point. After taking a test shot, you should make small adjustments.

Most of the time, you'll use an ISO between 1200 and 3200 for night photography, though a full moon or the northern lights might allow for an ISO as low as 800.

2. Work in Manual mode

You might find Manual mode intimidating at first. It's like going from riding a bike with training wheels to freewheeling down a hill. But stick with it. Mastering Manual mode gives you total control over your camera settings, and that's invaluable in landscape photography.

Manual mode allows you to tweak the aperture, shutter speed, and ISO independently. That way, you can carefully dial in your preferred settings, then make adjustments until you have the results you want.

Trial and error is part of the process. Take multiple shots with different settings. Look at them side by side. Understand how adjusting one parameter changes the outcome of your image. As you get the hang of it, operating in Manual mode will feel like second nature, and you'll wonder why you were ever so intimidated!

Spending the time to master Manual mode can really pay off. Your landscape shots will feature more detail, better exposure levels, and less noise. Plus, you'll develop a deeper understanding of how your camera truly works.

3. Don't be afraid to adjust the aperture instead of the ISO

The most difficult part of manually adjusting settings is learning what adjustments you need to make in certain situations. Should you adjust the ISO, aperture, or shutter speed? I remember this being one of my biggest frustrations when first making the switch to Manual mode .

While leading photography workshops, I often notice that many students are photographing with an aperture of f/22 and ISO 100.

Then, when they need a faster shutter speed, their first instinct is to increase the ISO.

As discussed above, it can make sense to boost your ISO for a faster shutter speed. But you should always ask yourself: Do I actually need such a narrow aperture ?

If you're shooting at f/22, for example, you might consider widening the aperture to f/16, f/11, or f/8. And if that will give you good results, leave the ISO alone.

Remember, always use the lowest ISO possible . In scenarios where you're shooting with f/22, the image will almost certainly benefit from using a wider aperture and maintaining a low ISO. This is true whether you're shooting during the day or at night.

4. Trust your technology

You might be thinking that ISO is a bit of a necessary evil. It can help you out in tricky light situations, but it can also bring unwanted noise into your photos. To a large extent, this is true – but modern cameras are pretty darn good at handling high ISOs.

Especially if you've got a camera that's on the newer side, you'll find that images shot at ISO 400 and even ISO 800 can be surprisingly clean. Gone are the days when ISO 400 would make your photo look like a grainy mess. Advances in sensor technology have changed the game.

What about even higher ISOs? You can venture into ISO 1600 or ISO 3200 territory and still get decent results, especially if you do some noise reduction later on (see the next tip!).

So what's the moral of the story here? Don't be afraid to push the boundaries. Your camera can likely handle more than you think. But don't just take my word for it. Run some tests. Take some sample shots at different ISOs and see how they turn out. It's the best way to gauge what you're comfortable with.

5. Use a good noise-reduction program

Noise at high ISOs is often pretty unsightly, but you don't have to live with it – there are amazing noise reduction programs that can remove noise while sacrificing minimal detail.

Many platforms come with noise reduction features built in. Take Lightroom, for example. It offers an AI Denoise feature that's pretty phenomenal. You can get rid of those specks and keep your photo's details crisp.

Now, what if you're really focused on image quality and don't mind spending a bit? There are standalone programs designed just for noise reduction. A popular one is DeNoise AI from Topaz Labs, which offers specialized tools to obliterate noise and enhance image quality.

Yes, you'll need to invest some money. But the results are excellent, so if you often need to add some denoising to your shots, it could be a worthwhile purchase.

6. Try a black-and-white conversion

Let's say you've tried noise reduction software, and you're still not happy. Maybe the noise is too stubborn, or it's affecting the colors in a way that can't be eliminated. Well, there's another trick you can try: a black-and-white conversion.

When you convert a noisy photo to black and white, something interesting happens. That noise starts to look like texture. Instead of detracting from your image, it can add a layer of grit. The result is often more forgiving of noise and can even be visually appealing, depending on the mood you're going for.

Converting to black and white is a breeze; most editors offer a one-click approach. Just find the right button, press it, and voilà, your image is instantly transformed. (And don't worry: you can still tweak the contrast, brightness, and other elements after the conversion.)

So if you find yourself stuck with a noisy image that won't clean up the way you want it to, give black and white a try. You might just discover that your “ruined” photo wasn't ruined at all. It just needed some fine-art editing!

The best ISO for landscape photography: final words

I hope that I haven't made you even more confused than you were before. Understanding the ISO and choosing the best one for your situation is a little tricky, as there isn't always one correct choice. However, what I hope you take away from this article is that you should aim to use the lowest possible ISO in each given scenario.

For regular daytime photography, you should typically use an ISO between 64 and 400 (the latter is when you're working with a telephoto lens handheld, which requires a quicker shutter speed to keep the photos sharp). For night photography, you should typically use an ISO between 1200 and 3200.

So as the final word on the best ISO for landscape photography:

There isn't one single correct ISO for each and every scenario. But aim to use the lowest ISO you can.
